title: Does the truth always include facts? - Quora

response.answer_text: As asked, I would say definitely not. As “facts" are many times based on societal expectation, most “facts" are actually arbitrary and culturally based. I think most truths include interpretations, and what defines an absolute truth is the absence of interpretation; something that does not depend on constructs such as words or numbers that describe it. The sky is blue…. That's interpretation. Is light diffracted as it passes through our atmosphere resulting in specific frequencies reaching out eyes? That's truth. Both could be considered “facts”.

A fact is just a snippet of information, usually but not always objective, that a certain amount of people agree on. Facts can and do change over time. The truth is a concept of an absolute thing that doesn’t change over time though interpretations of specific “truths” can change over time. Also, many things that are purported to be truth and/or facts are actually complete fiction. It’s possible to have a truth without any facts. For example a person could be in denial of the truth and hold onto all the facts that seem to contradict said truth. These things are all loose concepts anyway. It’s not like they’re mathematically defined extrapolations from the fundamental forces of the universe.
“No facts could be established, let alone agreed upon, regarding this case.” Ironically enough, the sentence above states a truth.
No. Truth does not have facts. If facts are there then it is mere information about truth.

The truth and fact are not synonomys, a fact need not be true, simply an item which supports a claim, opinion or theory. Truth is what has actually happened, happening or claimed which may or may not be factual or accurate, simply sincere in nature with no intent to mislead.
Truth is God, so only “Facts” about God can be true.
Not always, Truth can be tailored around facts.
